aws::graph::propositions: # Aviation Accident Report for Pitts S2C in Roseburg, Oregon
The accident occurred in Roseburg, Oregon.
The accident occurred on January 26, 2014, at 15:30 Local time.
The aircraft involved was a Pitts S2C.
The aircraft registration was N102ZT.
The defining event was collision during takeoff/land.
The flight was conducted under Part 91: General aviation - Personal.
The accident number was WPR14LA114.
The aircraft sustained substantial damage.
There were no injuries in the accident.
The pilot involved was a commercial pilot.
The pilot was conducting a local personal flight.
The pilot entered the traffic pattern behind a slower airplane.
The pilot observed a second high-wing airplane on an apparent base leg about 1 mile south of the airport.
The pilot made a right 360-degree turn while on the downwind leg for spacing.
The pilot reestablished his position on the downwind leg.
The pilot requested position reports from local area traffic.
The pilot in the first airplane reported being clear of the runway.
The accident pilot heard no other position reports.
The accident pilot began a normal approach to the runway.
A pilot from an unknown airplane transmitted that his airplane was on final for the same runway.
The accident pilot rolled the airplane wings level.
The accident pilot checked the final approach path for traffic.
The accident pilot observed no traffic.
The accident pilot rolled the airplane back into a left turn to final with a shallow left forward slip.
The airplane collided with the upper portion of a tall tree as it rolled onto short final.
The pilot landed the airplane successfully after the collision.
The Federal Aviation Administration Digital Airport/Facility Directory noted that the runway had a displaced threshold of 371 feet due to a tree.
The tree was depicted on the airport diagram.
The pilot likely lost his orientation with respect to the tree when he diverted his scan to look for another airplane in the traffic pattern.
The National Transportation Safety Board determined the probable cause of the accident to be the pilot's loss of orientation while scanning for airport traffic.
The pilot's loss of orientation resulted in his failure to maintain clearance from a tree.

text:
# Aviation Investigation Final Report

## Location:
Roseburg, Oregon

## Date & Time: 
January 26, 2014, 15:30 Local

## Aircraft:
Pitts S2C

## Defining Event:
Collision during takeoff/land

## Flight Conducted Under:
Part 91: General aviation - Personal

## Accident Number:
WPR14LA114

## Registration:
N102ZT

## Aircraft Damage:
Substantial

## Injuries:
1 None

## Analysis

The commercial pilot was conducting a local personal flight. The pilot reported that he entered the traffic pattern behind a much slower airplane and observed a second (high-wing) airplane on an apparent base leg about 1 mile south of the airport. The pilot made a right 360-degree turn while on the downwind leg for spacing. After reestablishing his position on the downwind leg, he requested position reports from local area traffic. The pilot in the first airplane in the traffic pattern reported clear of the runway; the accident pilot heard no other position reports and subsequently began a normal approach to the runway. Immediately before turning to final, the pilot from an unknown airplane transmitted that his airplane was on final for the same runway. The accident pilot then rolled the airplane wings level and checked the final approach path for traffic. He observed no traffic and subsequently rolled the airplane back into a left turn to final with a shallow left forward slip. As the airplane rolled onto short final, it collided with the upper portion of a tall tree. The pilot then landed the airplane successfully.

The Federal Aviation Administration Digital Airport/Facility Directory noted that the runway had a displaced threshold of 371 ft due to a tree, which was also depicted on the airport diagram. It is likely that the pilot lost his orientation with respect to the tree when he diverted his scan to look for another airplane in the traffic pattern.

## Probable Cause and Findings

The National Transportation Safety Board determines the probable cause(s) of this accident to be:

The pilot's loss of orientation while scanning for airport traffic during the turn from the base to final legs of the traffic pattern, which resulted in his failure to maintain clearance from a tree.

---
